awd_titl_txt: Near-field coupling between molecular vibrations and plasmonic metal oxide nanocrystals
awd_abstract_narration:
Chemists can grow extremely small crystals. The smallest crystals can be only a few nanometers in size, or about 100,000 times smaller than a sheet of paper.  These small crystals contain just a few thousand atoms. Some nanocrystals can concentrate light and the focused energy can be used in applications ranging from solar energy conversion to sensing.  However, a single type of nanocrystal can only concentrate a few colors of light. By changing its chemical composition, one can adjust this color for specific applications.  With support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program in the Division of Chemistry, Professor Delia Milliron at the University of Texas at Austin is growing nanocrystals that concentrate infrared light. While we cannot see infrared light, we feel it as heat from sunlight or a hot fire. Working with her students, Professor Milliron is studying how the size, shape, and composition of a nanocrystal influences its ability to concentrate infrared light. Their discoveries could lead to better ways of detecting specific chemicals and improved catalytic methods, which would have important benefits to society.   An interactive educational module regarding nanoscience and light-matter interactions is being adapted to reach diverse audiences, including high school students at Texas School for the Deaf and younger students who visit UT's campus for Girl Day and Explore UT, both are community-oriented outreach events.

This project targets the synthetic development of colloidal metal oxide nanocrystals (NCs) containing aliovalent dopants that induce a high concentration of free electrons, leading to localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) in the mid-infrared spectral region. Coupling between LSPR modes and the vibrational modes of proximal organic molecules is studied quantitatively. Most research on LSPR has focused on noble metals, which must be patterned into larger, micron-scale metal structures to reach mid-infrared frequencies. The limitations of that approach motivate the investigation of plasmonic metal oxide NCs. This is quantitatively establishing how NC physiochemical properties control the nature and strength of coupling between LSPR and vibrational modes, ultimately leading to the foundational understanding needed to develop sensitive and chemically specific detectors, and to direct the flow of energy to tune and enhance catalytic processes. The team is creating interactive educational activities that illustrate how the interaction of light and matter is used in modern applications, such as electronic displays and solar cells.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Plasmonic metal oxide nanocrystals (NCs) interact with light through their localized surface plasmon resonance (LSPR), confining the incoming light to nanoscopic volume and and greatly increasing the electric field near the NC surface—so called near field enhancement (NFE)—around their LSPR resonant frequency. The LSPR frequency is dependent on a number of physical parameters, chiefly among them the conduction band electron concentration (ne), which can be tuned during the synthesis of the NCs through the incorporation of dopant ions, or post-synthetically through chemical charging of the NC. This tunability is one of the major features which makes plasmonic metal oxide NCs particularly attractive, as a single material can be modified to meet a number of different applications, targeting the specific LSPR frequency which is needed for the application. Our goal was to build an understanding of the relationship between metal oxide NC physical parameters and their optical properties.

Towards this end, we developed a method for fitting the optical spectrum of a sample of NCs in order to determine ne, as well as the width of the surface depletion layer. The surface depletion layer is a region near the surface of the NC which has a lower ne due to surface defects and surface adsorbed molecules. This region insulates the NC from its environment, decreasing the NFE which is important for a number of applications such as catalysis and sensing. Our method, the heterogeneous ensemble Drude approximation (HEDA), expands the commonly used Drude approximation in order to account for variation in individual NC sizes and ne within the sample, as well as determines the width of the depletion layer. Using the HEDA method, we studied the impact of NC size, dopant density and distribution, as well as the impact of surface adsorbed molecules on the optical properties of tin-doped indium oxide (Sn:In2O3) NCs. We established that surface depletion plays a key role in electron transfer both to and from the NC, as well as the resulting tunability of their optical properties. We also found that surface adsorbed molecules tune the depletion width in a unique manner, increasing ne while simultaneously increasing the surface depletion width, providing a new method for modifying the properties of Sn:In2O3. We explored the impact of segregating Sn in the core versus the shell of  Sn:In2O3 on chemical charging of the NC, finding that core-doped Sn:In2O3 has a greater degree of optical tunability. Finally, we examined the role of surface depletion in fluorine co-doped Sn:In2O3 nanocubes, finding that depletion has a minimal impact on the nanocube corners, which is important because this is where the NFE is highest. These results expand our understanding of how to design metal oxide NCs for better charge storage and optical tunability, as well as the impact of surface depletion on their properties.

Outside of studying surface depletion, we also examined the role of the crystal structure in determining the electrochemical optical tunability of metal oxide NCs. We developed a method for synthesizing Nb12O29 nanorods (NRs) and nanoplatelets (NPLs), and found that the NPLs have greater visible light absorption due the structure dependence of lithion ion insertion. We compared the charging dynamics these NPLs to Nb2O5 NRs and Sn:In2O3 NCs, using carefully selected electrolyte solutions to differentiate between different mechanisms of electrochemical charging. Finally, we studied electrochemical modulation of the optical properties of cesium-doped tungsten oxide NCs, using different electrolyte solutions to show how ion insertion into different parts of the crystal leads to different optical responses. These results expand our understanding of how the crystal structure of metal oxide NCs impacts their electrochemical properties, as well as how different electrochemical charging mechanisms lead to different mechanisms of light absorption.

We established a synthetic approach which can modify the amount of oxygen incorporated into metal oxide NCs, changing the amount of defects that form. These defects change the amount of visible light that the NCs absorb, and can additionally change which crystal structure forms. This method is broadly applicable to other metal oxide systems, and likely other semiconductors, also.

Finally, we developed a computational method for calculating the optical properties of very large, complex arrangements of NCs. These systems are usually difficult to simulate due to the large number of particles (thousands) and the complicated interactions between these particles. Our method is able to efficiently handle these large systems, increasing our ability to study the optical properties of materials such as metal oxide NC gels, which have fractal networks of disordered arrangements of NCs.
